dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Nice to meet you, my name's Christopher.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Hey Christopher. And how old are you?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I'm ten.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: What grade is that?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think fifth.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: You think fifth? What is your favorite subject?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Math and science.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Well that's awesome, because we're going to be talking about science today.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Cool.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And you know what we're going to be talking about?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: What?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Sleep.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Favorite part of the day.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Mine too, because I get to spend all day studying it. Because you know what sleep does for you?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: It rests your body, like an electric car.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: [laughs] That's exactly right. It kinda is like recharging your battery, right? And sleep is so critical for so many parts of our body and our mind, right? It plays a really important way that we learn, and it helps us kind of recover from the day before. It affects our immune system and our metabolism, all of these things that we need to kinda be healthy.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Whoa.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So today, we're going to talk about some animals and how they sleep. So here's the first one. What's that?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: A giraffe.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Have you ever seen a giraffe in person?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Uh yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: They're pretty cool, right?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Mhm.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And so what's really cool about this is that giraffes need to sleep like everybody else, and so the way that it does is it kind of slumps over and it gets down on its legs and it kind of becomes this ball, but what's crazy about the whole thing is they only sleep for like 30 minutes a day. 30 minutes! Because it can't waste any more time, because it can't be vulnerable for any longer. It can get eaten by lions and that kind of thing. It has kind of evolved in a way that it can still survive and still get all the restoration it needs under such a short period of time.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: And how does it like recharge, like humans?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So we think it works the same way, but maybe just like more efficiently. And so we're still really learning about how this works. Sleep science itself is kind of a new field.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I had a sleepover on Saturday, and I didn't sleep at all.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And how did you feel?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Really tired.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Really tired. Do you think you were a little crankier than usual? Yeah. That's actually really interesting, because what happens is humans and everything needs to sleep eventually, and so you can't stay up indefinitely, right? What do you think happens if you don't sleep?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: It affects what you can do in your daily life.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Excellent. So now I want to tell you about another animal and how they sleep, okay? So we have this one. What's that?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: A hippo.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: A hippopotamus. They have a different challenge. They sleep underwater.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I could never do that, I would pass out.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Right, right! So how do they do it? In the area that they live in, they need to stay cool, right? And so they spend a lot of time in the water, and so then as a consequence, they need to sleep in the water, but how do they do it? So it's really fascinating. What they do is while they're sleeping, they actually float back up to the surface and breathe without waking up. They're able to go about their whole sleep cycles but still able to breathe, because their body has adapted in a way that they can still get the oxygen that they need. It's a really amazing thing. What do you think?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That's cool.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Would it be cool to have that power?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Uh yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So now I want to talk about our last animal, and I think this one is probably the most amazing of all. Okay, so what's this?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Aww a dolphin.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: A dolphin! Yes. So dolphins, kind of like hippos, have to sleep in the water, okay? But because they're mammals, right, they need to breathe. Dolphins breathe air. They have to go up to the surface and breathe, right? And for an animal like that, it needs to figure out a way that it can sleep but also still survive, right? You know how dolphins sleep?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: How?

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: One half of their brain at a time. So half of their brain goes to sleep, and the other half stays awake, so that they can continue to breathe and swim, and they do it in this four hours a time, so like their right part of their brain sleeps, they're able to go up to the surface and breathe. Then their left part of their brain sleeps for four hours, and it goes back and forth, back and forth, so they can kind of maintain alertness, still breathe, and survive. Is that amazing or what?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: That's cool.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So what'd you learn today?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I learned how other animals sleep.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: What is important about sleeping?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Sleep rests your body, and you have to rest your body in order to do your daily things in life.
